intro: Napus leucosinapsis, commonly known as the white cabbage. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its cruciform flowers and elongated, fleshy leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with a rosette of basal leaves and a flowering stem that bears a terminal inflorescence. Its flowers are white or pale yellow, with four petals arranged in a cross shape, typical of the family. The plant is known for its edible leaves and is cultivated in temperate regions for both culinary and agricultural purposes.
